resources.string: The upperparts of the bird refers to the back of the bird, including the back of the neck, wings and top of the tail. The underparts of a bird refers mainly to the belly of the bird. The primary underparts and upperparts colours are exactly what they sound like. Ask yourself: What colour do I see most on the bird\'s upper/underparts? You can then select the option provided that suits your assessment best. \nThere are two colours that are a bit weird and you might not have heard of them or maybe you just need a reminder of how they look. Those colours are \'rufuous\' and \'olive\'. You can see these colours in the image below. Think of rufuous as a rusty brown red, while olive is a dark yellowish-green colour. Please note that there can be lighter shades of rufuous, just consider something that is rust-coloured as rufuous.
The bill shape refers to the general shape of the bird\'s bill/beak from the view of the average person. So, the bill shapes can be described by the following features\n

Think of the primary colour of the bird\'s bill as the main colour of the bird\'s bill. If you think a bird has a bill that is black and white, you should choose the colour that you think covers the bill the most. As long as you make your best guess as to what the bill colour is, then you should get the results you want.

Note that the height we are talking about here is not the distance between the bird\'s head and the ground. Here, the height refers to the distance between the tip of the bird\'s bill and the tip of the bird\'s tail when the bird is laid out flat. This can be challenging to visualize at first but you will get the hang of it!
Which habitat did you spot it in?

NO BIRDS MATCH THAT COMBINATION OF CHARACTERISTICS

The search bar is useful for searching for a specific bird either by their common name or scientific name. You can choose which name to search by with the use of the two buttons above the search bar which are labelled as such. Below the search bar is a list of all of the birds at Intaka Island with either their common or scientific name depending on your preference. You may either scroll through this list to find the bird you are looking for, or type the name into the search bar to find the bird. Once you find the bird that you are looking for, you may click on it to reveal a page displaying information about the bird as well as an image of the bird. On the Bird Information page, you may scroll through the features and description of the bird to learn more about the bird. Additionally, you can add the bird to your list of spottings, by clicking the eye button next to the bird image.

This feature is useful for identifying a bird you are looking at by describing its features. After clicking on this button on the home page you will be taken to a screen with 5 questions. Answer these questions in a manner that best describes the bird you are looking at and click submit. After clicking submit, you will be taken to a screen which displays all the birds that match at least four of the features you provided. You may click on the bird names to view what the bird looks like and determine if it is the right bird. When clicking on the bird names, you are taken to the respective bird information display page for that specific bird. Once you find the bird you were looking for from the results, you may go through their specific information page.

The spottings screen displays a list of all of the birds you have spotted and added to your bird spottings. If you click on a spotting, you will be directed to the respective bird information screen for the specific bird which was clicked on. If you wish to delete a spotting, click the bin icon at the top of the screen. This will direct you to a page where you may select a spotting to delete, or delete all of your spottings by clicking the “Delete All” button. Once clicking on a spotting or the delete all button, you will be asked to confirm your deletion. Once the deletion is confirmed, you can either choose to return to the spottings page or to delete more spottings.

If you wish to add a bird spotting you may do so by clicking the eye button next to the bird image on the bird information display page. You will then be asked to select the habitat in which the spotting occurred. This is the point in the map grid provided where the bird spotting took place. Finally, you can select the date of the spotting and click the add spotting button. You will then be directed to the spotting page, with your new spotting added to your list.

The map screen can be opened from the Home Screen by clicking on the map button. This screen displays the map that is given to visitors upon entry to Intaka Island. On this screen, you may zoom into the map and scroll around it to help you in navigating around Intaka Island.
If you click on the information button on the home page, you will be directed to a screen which displays some information about Intaka Island.

Intaka Island, an award-winning 16 hectare wetlands and bird sanctuary, is home to 177 species of indigenous fynbos plants and 120 bird species. Intaka – which means ‘bird’ in Xhosa – is a unique example of nature conservation and urban development co-existing in harmony. Apart from its environmental significance, the area offers a place of solace to take a stroll, relax, and get away from the hustle and bustle of everyday life
Location: Grand Central Precinct, 2 Park Ln, Century City, Cape Town, 7441, South Africa

October – April:
 Monday – Sunday: 08h00 – 19h00 daily

 May – September:
 Monday – Sunday: 08h00 – 17h30 daily

 Open every day of the year, except 25 December.

Intaka boasts 120 different bird species in a safe, easy-to-reach area due to the diversity of Intaka Islands 7 different habitats. The terrestrial habitat of fynbos, shrubs and grasses attracts birds like the Cape Francolin, Weavers and Cape Sparrows. The shrub areas provide safe foraging areas for Cape White-Eyes, Robin Chats and Spotted Prinias while the open water is suitable for the Cape Shoveller, Yellow Billed Duck, Red Knobbed Coot and Moorhen. Reed Beds provide food and nesting for the Little Bittern, Purple Swamphen, Masked Weaver, Red Bishop and Levaillant’s Cisticola.\n
With bird-watching being one of the fastest growing recreational activities, Intaka Island offers birdwatchers and nature enthusiasts in general a unique opportunity to discover and study our birds up close in their natural habitat.\n
A number of birds also make use of the man made heronries on Intaka Island for breeding and roosting. These heronries have been recognized internationally for both their simple construction and success at attracting birds.
For more information about Intaka Island, please visit www.intaka.co.za
